messageBody:
Moira:

Welcome. I am so glad you found us. About 1974, I also wrote to
Kingsley Read, but my correspondence with him was very brief. He
supplied me with the names of two people who were interested in
corresponding -- one in New Zealand and one in Oregon or Washington
state here in the U.S. The latter person is a member of this group
although he has not written in quite some time.

Around 1999, after I found a group promoting Shavian, as they call the
alphabet which won the contest held due to Shaw's will, I talked to
people in that group regarding QS, but found they had little interest in
it. Some of their members were developing computer fonts so that
Shavian could be typed on their computers, but no one was interested in
doing the same for QS. I did not have the necessary expertise to design
a QS font so I stayed in the Shavian group for the time being.

When I first became a member, I expected more interest to be shown in QS
since I viewed it as the tested and revised version of Shavian. It
quickly became obvious that the Shavian group did not see things that
way. To most of them, QS was an ill-advised revision of Read's work --
sort of a heresy, in fact. I was told that the publication of
_Androcles and the Lion_ in the bi-alphabetic format had given Shavian
so much more publicity than QS had been able to achieve that it made no
sense to champion QS. This is a viewpoint I did not and do not agree
with. If the designer of the alphabet felt the his initial attempt
(Shavian) needed improvement to make it fully practicable among
English-speaking communities around the world, which I assume was his
rationale for releasing QS to the world, then it makes little sense to
continue using and promoting the "beta" form of the alphabet. I was
told that switching to QS would toss aside the progress they had made.
Of course at that time, the Shavian group had about 100 members, if
memory serves, so the "progress" had not been exactly overwhelming.

I finally became sufficiently exasperated with the comments made about
QS in the Shavian group and their lack of interest that I resolved to
start the Read_Alphabet (RA) group myself in late November, 2000. Jon
Zuck, one of our members (he designed the first QS font), tried to
dissuade me from it. I believe he was concerned that it would splinter
the interest in alternative English alphabets between the two groups,
but, in fact, RA has done quite well. We have over 300 members now. I
would like to see the group continue to grow. RA seems to attract a
somewhat different type of member than Shavian does. They love to
debate every miniscule aspect of Shavian, but the feeling I have is that
most of our members seem more interested in using the alphabet as a tool
and less interested in the theory behind it.

Due to the difficulties of getting various varieties of browsers to work
properly with QS fonts, we tend to write in the Roman alphabet, or as it
is sometimes called, traditional orthography (TO), which is ironic. I
believe that lots of practice is needed to increase reading speed and if
it were easier to write in QS over the internet, that would make it
simpler for people to improve their QS skills. I still am not
completely happy with the QS fonts we have available, although Kingsley
is quite good. Jerome - the first font for QS -- will even let you use
half-letters, but there was a problem at times with the spacing of the
letters and the positioning of the cursor. There is information on the
group site that tells you how to use the fonts. Another issue is that
standard keyboards don't have enough keys for QS so the issue of how to
set up the keyboard has found different solutions. I don't think an
ideal has been reached there either.

I hope the foregoing has given you some background of our group. I am
sure that members of the group would enjoy reading some of your
reminiscences of your correspondence with Kingsley Read. I do not
believe any other member had the privilege of meeting Mr. Read so the
story of your trip to his home would be delightful.

Paige Gabhart
Jeffersonville, Indiana USA

Moira wrote:

> I had the great privilege of corresponding with Kingsley Read in
> QuikSript in a small circle of friends in England and Northern Ireland,
> and then being invited to stay for a weekend with Kingsley in his
> lovely cottage in the Vale of Evesham.
>
> Sadly, real life took over in teh early 70's and I lost touch with the
> correspondence group and with with Kinglsey but I never lost my
> interest in QuikScript and, after finding myself using it (very
> rustily) in a course I am undertaking, my interest was rekindled
> resulting in my finding this group.
>
> I am delighted to find that QS is still alive and kicking and not just
> residing in the libraries for academic research.
>
> I will be pleased to talk to any other enthusiasts and look for4ward to
> browsing through the past postings in this group.
>
> Moira O'Brien
> Cork, Ireland
>
>
